ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was online and synchronous.
virtual seminar with video and audio on when possible and use of breakout rooms

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my German skills, mostly my writing skills.
I improved my german skills and learned a lot about fairy tales and their meaning and purpose.
learned about German fairytales and their history and cultural relevance today
Lots of new vocab relating to fairy tales, practiced grammar that I hadnt had much experience with. Very familiar with German fairy tales now and their common characteristics.

I gained a deep understanding of German fairytales, stereotypes and themes they perpetuate and how they have maintained relevance and a rich legacy today.

I also practiced my German speaking and writing skills, even making a 10 minute radio-show video that was unlike any assignment I had previously done in German.

I learned about the intricacies of German fairy tales both in literary and cultural contexts. We explored themes like the representation of gender roles in fairy tales, their importance in children's development, the role of animals, etc.
I learned how to interpret fairy tales from several standpoints--ranging from the field of psychoanalysis to psychology, sociology, and anthropology. I also significantly improved my language skills.
Knowledge about fairy tales in German and their cultural and social impact and increased familiarity with advanced grammatical structures.
My German skills (speaking, writing, and reading) improved a lot. I also learned a lot about German fairy tales and the surprising (at least to me) amount of scholarly literature written about them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my knowledge of German, especially writing, and my capacity to read academic texts in German.

Strengths - lectures were fun and topics were interesting 
Weaknesses - more specific feedback/help on assignments rather than stating what was incorrect
Strengths: great content, helpful and interesting assignments, very engaging discussion breakout groups that constantly rotated

Strengths: The professors are INCREDIBLE - I have never met two instructors who cared more about their students and our learning of the German language. They were always so accommodating and made going to class so fun, especially in a virtual environment where Zoom burnout is real. The class always keeps you interested, because we constantly were watching videos, giving presentations, and going into breakout rooms, where we did so many different types of activities - answering discussion questions, retelling the fairy tale we read and drawing the stories' events, playing Kahoot, etc. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the secondary texts were very difficult to read, but by the end of the course the professors (Theresa and Shira) were great at highlighting the most important sections and giving us guiding discussion questions beforehand.

It was well-structured and the readings were always pertinent and very interesting. Also, both instructors were very enthusiastic. I wish we spent more time lingering on the ambiguities of literary criticism.

Strengths: Lovely professor who is so, so passionate about the subject matter and also, a really fascinating subject matter. Annotated readings are also very helpful and workload is very reasonable. Honestly, no weaknesses!

The material of this course is very interesting, and it was always a joy to attend because of the discussion format. Occasionally the readings were very daunting (though interesting and rewarding), which was helped by the annotated versions which were available towards the latter half of the semester, but those could have been useful at the start as well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Schenker and Dr. Miron went above and beyond to make the class as interactive as possible. They used breakout rooms, cahoot games, a game on the last day of the class, presentations, discussion question submission, video submissions as response to discussion section as part of the homework and having different types of homework for each week. I think that all were very successful and the class was overall very engaging and very well organized yet often too fast for my pace.

Given the need to be virtual, this course fared as well as a course could, in my opinion. The small breakout rooms that constantly switched allowed me to get to know my classmates in a way unusual for virtual learning.

My virtual engagement remained incredibly high due to the diversity of activities we did during class (Kahoots, interviews, discussion questions, grammar exercises, presentations, drawing the fairy tales, etc.). Great use of breakout rooms! I don't have any suggestions on what could be improved - Theresa and Shira did a fantastic job of shifting this course to a virtual environment.
I think the virtual seminar format was effective. The Kahoot quizzes and other classroom activities were also useful, but I wish the course had looked a bit more academic and less "high schoolish".

Just the fact that this was a seminar-style class allowed for built-in engagement. Video and microphone were requested to be on at all times if possible in order to best bring an in-person environment to the Zoom room. Frequent and appropriate use of breakout rooms also made it possible to participate in small-group and class settings.

I think the discussion format worked well, despite being online. Breakout rooms were also useful and generally productive. I wasn't a fan of the virtual learning day, however, and felt like the work took longer than a regular class would have.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Professor Schenker is a great professor that always is supportive to students. The topic is also interesting. One thing I would note is that the class might be (sometimes) intimidating depending on your previous preparation.
i would definitely recommend this course. the topics are entertaining and the work was manageable.
Yes!
yes, Theresa's great. Just be ready to do lots of work and put in lots of time to keep up with the material. Also requires lots of student engagement.
Yes! Wonderful course, very interesting subject matter, not too intense.

Yes, most strongly! This course was incredibly interesting and engaging with a well balanced and spread out workload. The instructions and grading were very clear and the teacher was incredibly engaging.

I would absolutely recommend this course, if Theresa and Shira are teaching it again. They are so passionate about the material, and know how to make every single class different and fun. Know that the workload can be a bit heavy at times, just because you have to keep track of weekly assignments (vocabulary lists, creative tasks), and also keep up with the readings. That being said, however, reading the fairy tales themselves never felt like a chore (unlike many of my readings in other classes), and we often were given links to movies that we could watch instead! Fantastic course that will be so different in contrast to the other classes you are taking. If you're trying to improve your German grammar, this class might not be for you - but you definitely still get to practice your German and improve it more conversationally!
Yes, I would! It's exciting to delve into original fairy tales and study their symbolic meanings. It's also great to be improving your German with Theresa, who always makes it fun to learn new stuff.

Yes!!! Take it! If you're not completely swept off your feet by a class about fairy tales (amazing!) then you will still be taking a very well-organized, challenging, yet manageable and rewarding class. Do it!!!
Absolutely. Theresa and Shira were both great, the material is extremely interesting, your German skills will definitely improve, and the discussion with classmates is always fun.
